gloria.performance_metrics#

gloria.performance_metrics(data, metric_name, timestamp_name, horizon_period, performance_metrics=None)[source]#

Evaluate cross-validation forecasts with a suite of error and coverage metrics.

The function ingests the DataFrame returned by cross_validation() and computes the metrics listed below:

  • mse - mean squared error*

  • rmse - root mean squared error

  • mae - mean absolute error

  • mape - mean absolute percentage error

  • smape - symmetric mean absolute percentage error

  • mdape - median absolute percentage error

  • smdape - symmetric median absolute percentage error

  • coverage - share of observations that fall between the lower and upper prediction bounds

Every metric except for coverage is computed via the corresponding implementation of sktime.performance_metrics.

Parameters:

  • data (pandas.DataFrame) – The dataframe returned by cross_validation().

  • metric_name (str) – The name of the metric column.

  • timestamp_name (str) – The name of the timestamp column.

  • horizon_period (pandas.Timedelta | str) –

    Width of the horizon bins used to aggregate errors by lead time (distance between cutoff and prediction timestamp). For example, with horizon_period="3d":

    • 0 - 3 days ahead → bin "3d"

    • 3 - 6 days ahead → bin "6d"

    • …

    This fixed-width binning differs from Prophet’s performance_metrics, which widens the window until a target number of forecasts is included.

  • performance_metrics (list[str] | None) – Subset of metrics to compute. If None (default), all metrics above are returned.

Returns:

result – Table indexed by horizon bin and containing every requested metric plus a "count" column with the number of forecasts in each bin.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame
